messages.subject: Tsuba Geijutsu Ko
messages.msgSnippet: All, I am on the lookout for a copy of Tsuba Geijutsu Ko, The book by Torigoye, not the translation from the NCJSC which I already have. If anyone knows of one
messages.messageBody:
All, I am on the lookout for a copy of Tsuba Geijutsu Ko, The book by
Torigoye, not the translation from the NCJSC which I already have. If
anyone knows of one that is available, I would appreciate knowing about it.

Cheers

Rich Turner

messages.subject: Re: Jersey City sword show...  question for Gordon ( again )
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Milt I think there is a name --- machi-okuri.  :) So just wondering if a small hagiri under the habaki is the reason that blades become machi-okuri. later
messages.messageBody:
Dear Milt

I think there is a name --- machi-okuri. :)

So just wondering if a small hagiri under the habaki is the reason
that blades become machi-okuri.

later
david

Re: Jersey City sword show... question for Gordon ( again )
Posted by: "bungotakadasword" MuramasaIII@... bungotakadasword
Sat Sep 16, 2006 9:23 pm (PST)
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Robson <robsongo@...> wrote:
>
> Had a good time. Enjoyed seeing lots of familiar faces and some good
> swords. People are still submitting stuff they shouldn't, however. I
> do hope the level of study continues to improve. A lot of the guys
> who have been with this for some time now did very well with some
> only getting one or two rejections.

>Gordon,
>to avoid submitting stuff i shouldn't, have a question for
>you...........

>If the " hagiri " appears right below the hamachi, by definition it is
>not a " hagiri " since it is located on the nakago, yes ?

>So if I have a sword with hagiri ( hidden under the habaki ), just
>above the hamachi, and if I have Big Mo " reshape the nakago just a
>little and also " move up " the hamachi.........wella, no more hagiri ??

>Would the shinsa team pinkie it just because there's a nakagogiri ( the
>term doesn't exist, I check the books........ =) )?

>Not that I would submit this as you promise previously a special pink
>sheet for me..........just curious.

>Milt

--
David McDonald Collector of Japanese Swords and Old Iron
PO Box 265 WEB page - http://www.montanairon.com
Sidney MT 59270 email - jswords@...
406-482-3243 evenings I do tsukamaki (wrapping of sword hilts)

Owner of White IH Cub & Super A Farmall, IH 100 & 130, 140, AC G
McD type M, Monitor, Frost King and other stationary engines.

messages.subject: Re: Jersey City sword show...  question for Gordon ( again )
messages.msgSnippet: ... Gordon, to avoid submitting stuff i shouldn t, have a question for you........... If the  hagiri  appears right below the hamachi, by definition it is
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Robson <robsongo@...> wrote:
>
> Had a good time. Enjoyed seeing lots of familiar faces and some good
> swords. People are still submitting stuff they shouldn't, however. I
> do hope the level of study continues to improve. A lot of the guys
> who have been with this for some time now did very well with some
> only getting one or two rejections.

Gordon,
to avoid submitting stuff i shouldn't, have a question for
you...........

If the " hagiri " appears right below the hamachi, by definition it is
not a " hagiri " since it is located on the nakago, yes ?

So if I have a sword with hagiri ( hidden under the habaki ), just
above the hamachi, and if I have Big Mo " reshape the nakago just a
little and also " move up " the hamachi.........wella, no more hagiri ??

Would the shinsa team pinkie it just because there's a nakagogiri ( the
term doesn't exist, I check the books........ =) )?

Not that I would submit this as you promise previously a special pink
sheet for me..........just curious.

Milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Jersey City sword show............ a suggestion, if I may
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, With the hawk count shut down due to rainy weather I m catching up on things post-shinsa. The fittings shinsa team this time around took quite a lot of
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
With the hawk count shut down due to rainy weather I'm catching up on things post-shinsa.

The fittings shinsa team this time around took quite a lot of time scratching our heads to come up with informative attributions on the mumei stuff. There were quite a few attributions to schools and groups. The problem simply is that for many pieces there is nothing distinctive enough about the workmanship or quality to go beyond just Kyo, Edo or Mito Kinko. Throwing out something more specific isn't going to help anyone learn if there are multiple other groups turning out work of the same style.

Honestly I found my self thinking several times "why would someone submit this item to shinsa?" You want to give the customer his money's worth, but there's very little that can be said about the piece. It's kind of like being handed a T-shirt and being asked which fashion design house it came from.

Jim


----- Original Message -----
From: bungotakadasword
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, September 09, 2006 12:43 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Jersey City sword show............ a suggestion, if I may


we were discussing on another sword list about the shinsa paper.
Specifically the paper on mumei fittings that passed.
Quite often, we get the passing origami attributing the piece to just "
Kyo kinko ".
A suggestion if I may............. how about the shinsa team be a
little bit more specific in the attribution ( mumei fittings ), say for
example " kyo kinko in the style of so and so ", rather than just Kyo
kinko ?
This would help the collectors in further study, yes ?

Milt





[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: Jersey City sword show............ a suggestion, if I may
messages.msgSnippet: Moses, I have kept all e-mails between us since sending you the blade (July 12, 2005). The only mention in regards to the Boshi was that it was hard to see .
messages.messageBody:
Moses,

I have kept all e-mails between us since sending you the blade (July
12, 2005). The only mention in regards to the Boshi was that it
was 'hard to see'. It was never said to me that it was missing or
running off. I also had no idea this was considered a fatal flaw.

It would have been all right to tell me that polishing would not
make the Boshi appear. And at that point, I would have probably ask
for the blade returned to me. As far as the NTHK (or any other group)
and their Shinsa, all I wanted was their opinion as to whether the
blade was Sue-Bizen or Shinto-Bizen.

As I told you before, I have learned from this experience and that
is good. I don't hold anything against anybody. I will continue to
ask questions of you and do future business with you. All is well!

Elliott




--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Moses Becerra" <kenzento@...>
wrote:
>
> I am surprised at this email Elliott. I recommended Shinsa
because
> overall the sword was in good condition. The Boshi was a gamble
but
> worth trying. I did tell you before the Shinsa all of this didn't
I?
>
> Moses Becerra
>
>
>

course,

I am surprised at this email Elliott. I recommended Shinsa because
overall the sword was in good condition. The Boshi was a gamble but
worth trying. I did tell you before the Shinsa all of this didn't I?

Moses Becerra

messages.subject: Re: Jersey City sword show............ a suggestion, if I may
messages.msgSnippet: I did not know that a Boshi running off the tip was considered a fatal flaw. Thats why I joined this group. To learn. And of course, polishing the blade would
messages.messageBody:
I did not know that a Boshi running off the tip was considered a
fatal flaw. Thats why I joined this group. To learn. And of course,
polishing the blade would not make the Boshi come back. Actually,
this blade did not need a polish, everything was in place (except
for the missing temper line). I am surprized that Moses didn't point
this out to me and recommend possibly not submitting it for Shinsa.
Again, this is all part of learning.

Thank you both (Paul & Rich) for furthering my education.

Elliott

if the hamon runs off the sword would not paper unless it was an

early and by a top smith.

does the temper run off the kissaki, if so, is this
> not a fatal flaw and not being an historically important piece,
would

> Cheers

> > Hakusui papered it to Shinto Sukesada. I have it from reliable

Anyway, I

kissaki.

more

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Jersey City sword show............ a suggestion, if I may
messages.msgSnippet: just to balance the comment made earlier, yes I agree with Rich, if the hamon runs off the sword would not paper unless it was an historically important smith
messages.messageBody:
just to balance the comment made earlier, yes I agree with Rich, if the hamon runs off the sword would not paper unless it was an historically important smith or blade. I have seen 1 Juyo where there is apparently no boshi. cant remember who by but it was very early and by a top smith.

Richard Turner <ikkanshi@...> wrote: Just a curiosity, does the temper run off the kissaki, if so, is this
not a fatal flaw and not being an historically important piece, would
not paper with any group.

Cheers

Rich

elliottshogun wrote:

> I agree with Paul, the NTHK should say something about the piece
> they are about to 'pink slip'. My blade was given a pink slip
> without any comment about it at all. As I stated earlier, Inami

> sources that only Koto smiths used Bizen Kuni Ju Osafune -. This
> prefix is Sue-Bizen. Shinto Bizen used Bizen Osafune Ju -. Anyway, I
> was disappointed that the only explanation given was that they would
> not Shinsa it due to the 'temper line' running off in the kissaki.
> Oh well, I will bring it to next years SF Token Kai and get all
> sorts of opinions.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Jersey City sword show............ a suggestion, if I may
messages.msgSnippet: Just a curiosity, does the temper run off the kissaki, if so, is this not a fatal flaw and not being an historically important piece, would not paper with any
messages.messageBody:
Just a curiosity, does the temper run off the kissaki, if so, is this
not a fatal flaw and not being an historically important piece, would
not paper with any group.

Cheers

Rich

messages.subject: Re: Jersey City sword show............ a suggestion, if I may
messages.msgSnippet: I agree with Paul, the NTHK should say something about the piece they are about to pink slip . My blade was given a pink slip without any comment about it at
messages.messageBody:
I agree with Paul, the NTHK should say something about the piece
they are about to 'pink slip'. My blade was given a pink slip
without any comment about it at all. As I stated earlier, Inami
Hakusui papered it to Shinto Sukesada. I have it from reliable
sources that only Koto smiths used Bizen Kuni Ju Osafune -. This
prefix is Sue-Bizen. Shinto Bizen used Bizen Osafune Ju -. Anyway, I
was disappointed that the only explanation given was that they would
not Shinsa it due to the 'temper line' running off in the kissaki.
Oh well, I will bring it to next years SF Token Kai and get all
sorts of opinions.

Elliott

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Jersey City sword show............ a suggestion, if I may
messages.msgSnippet: Dont agree Rich, If a novice (or indeed anyone else)  submits something they have no clue about I think it would be useful at least to be told what the tsuba/
messages.messageBody:
Dont agree Rich, If a novice (or indeed anyone else) submits something they have no clue about I think it would be useful at least to be told what the tsuba/ sword etc was trying to be. using a catch-all Bungo-Takada, echizen seki, or shiomi attribution does little to advance their knowledge. At least if they were told what it was copying they could look at originals and see the differences.
Also I am not sure (though I have never had to do it) why saying "Kyo-kinko in the style of" need necessarily take much more time. I would assume the panel would know what the artist was trying to emulate to be able to dismiss it as a copy.
Sorry if this is too simplistic, Im the same with software, I always think problems are easy to solve but then I dont have to do it!!

Richard Turner <ikkanshi@...> wrote:
I cannot see how it would help in studies ? To say "in the style of X"
would never work as it is just speculation, and many artists worked in
multiple styles. It may say that it was made by this school in the style
of that school, but that would not help identify the work any easier
would it ?. Just that it looks like something that school made. Also,
the submitter could just do this himself no ?

Rich

Gordon Robson wrote:
>
> I expect to do something like that might take a very great deal of time.
> Basically Kyokinko is pretty close to Bungo Takada :-)
>
> Gordon
>
> -
>
>
>

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of bungotakadasword
Sent: Saturday, September 09, 2006 1:43 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Jersey City sword show............ a suggestion,
if I may



we were discussing on another sword list about the shinsa paper.
Specifically the paper on mumei fittings that passed.
Quite often, we get the passing origami attributing the piece to just "
Kyo kinko ".
A suggestion if I may............. how about the shinsa team be a
little bit more specific in the attribution ( mumei fittings ), say for
example " kyo kinko in the style of so and so ", rather than just Kyo
kinko ?
This would help the collectors in further study, yes ?

Milt





[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: Jersey City sword show...
messages.msgSnippet: Let me tell you my story...........I sent a Katana to Moses B. for polishing. This blade is suriage and the Mei that is present is Bizen (no) Kuni Ju
messages.messageBody:
Let me tell you my story...........I sent a Katana to Moses B. for
polishing. This blade is suriage and the Mei that is present
is 'Bizen (no) Kuni Ju Osafune'(cut). This blade has paper from
Inami Hakusui. He papered it to a Shinto Sukesada. From my studies
and the opinion of others, only Koto blades were signed as above
(Bizen Kuni Ju Osafune (name)).

Moses and I decided to submit it to the NY NTHK Shinsa to learn
their opinion. I haven't heard from Moses yet but am very curious.
Did they even give it paper? As soon as I hear, I will let you know
the out come.




--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Mark Conneran" <conneranm@...>
wrote:
>

presumptuous

Obviously a

shinsa

to be

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Jersey City sword show...
messages.msgSnippet: For what it s worth, as a potential new-bee , I thought I d be presumptuous enough to make a few observations regarding the Jersey City show. I came up to the
messages.messageBody:
For what it's worth, as a potential "new-bee", I thought I'd be presumptuous
enough to make a few observations regarding the Jersey City show. I came up
to the show with a friend, hoping to take in a lecture or two. Obviously a
lot of work went into it. A few thoughts, for what it's worth, as
constructive criticism. We went to the taikai and skipped the shinsa
thinking that the latter would only be for those submitting swords to be
evaluated. The taikai was worthwhile for the budo demonstrations alone. The
swords in the sword display, however, were not labeled and we were, of
course, curious to know what it was we were viewing.

We are both members of JSS/US but haven't attended any of the NY club
meetings and really have little sword knowledge. As such I'm enormously
impressed by the knowledge of the members of this list. But from the
comments I've seen here earlier discussing the need to attract "new blood",
I think activities such as the "introduction to sword handling" lecture
might perhaps be expanded and publicized. Again, for what it's worth.

Mark Conneran



-----Original Message-----
From: Gordon Robson <robsongo@...>
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 7 Sep 2006 14:46:39 +0900
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Jersey City sword show...


It would be funny, if it were not so sad. This list and a shinsa
should be a serious opportunity for learning. I hope that people can
learn from a shinsa. I also encourage everyone to ask questions.
There were too few people who picked up their pieces and did not ask
for an explanation. Next time, if there is one for you, ask the guy
taking your money to call me over. I will be happy, or not, to
explain anything you want to know. That is why we are doing a shinsa.
Not to make you feel bad, but to try and share some knowledge with
you. If I was hard on Ted, I am sorry. If Ted would like to contact
me off line, I would be happy to help him understand his results. We
are doing another shinsa in Chicago next April. Please use this
opportunity to learn. Also, if anyone would like to volunteer to help
out along with Milt, let me know and you can share in the process.

Gordon

On Sep 7, 2006, at 11:46 AM, nihontochicken wrote:

> --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Ron Hartmann" <swords@...>
> wrote:

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Jersey City sword show...
messages.msgSnippet: It would be funny, if it were not so sad. This list and a shinsa should be a serious opportunity for learning. I hope that people can learn from a shinsa. I
messages.messageBody:
It would be funny, if it were not so sad. This list and a shinsa
should be a serious opportunity for learning. I hope that people can
learn from a shinsa. I also encourage everyone to ask questions.
There were too few people who picked up their pieces and did not ask
for an explanation. Next time, if there is one for you, ask the guy
taking your money to call me over. I will be happy, or not, to
explain anything you want to know. That is why we are doing a shinsa.
Not to make you feel bad, but to try and share some knowledge with
you. If I was hard on Ted, I am sorry. If Ted would like to contact
me off line, I would be happy to help him understand his results. We
are doing another shinsa in Chicago next April. Please use this
opportunity to learn. Also, if anyone would like to volunteer to help
out along with Milt, let me know and you can share in the process.

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Jersey City sword show...
messages.msgSnippet: ... I was not able to make it for the show and had two swords I was going to submit for shinsa. One already had NBTHK attribution at Juyo level and as it was a
messages.messageBody:
<robsongo@...> writes:

> Had a good time. Enjoyed seeing lots of familiar faces and some good
> swords. People are still submitting stuff they shouldn't, however. I
> do hope the level of study continues to improve. A lot of the guys
> who have been with this for some time now did very well with some
> only getting one or two rejections. Nonetheless, the younger and less
> experienced guys need some guidance. I think the clubs are best for
> that. Still, when the front desk tells you not to submit your
> numbered and stamped gunto and you do anyway, I guess there is not
> much that can be done. We are trying to have a traveling shinsa every
> year with Chicago up next. I hope we can continue to see fewer
> rejections. Oh, the show also seems to have been well attended on
> Saturday. I gave a short talk similar to the one in San Francisco,
> and it was a pretty good turn out for a one off event.

> Gordon

I was not able to make it for the show and had two swords I was going to
submit for shinsa. One already had NBTHK attribution at Juyo level and
as it was a mumei, I was interested in alternate attributions.

As I didn't make it, neither were submitted.

Does the NTHK accept such blades? I was told somewhat vaguely that they
may not so I would like to know if I should bother submitting things
like this in the future?

Thanks,

- darcy

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Jersey City sword show...
messages.msgSnippet: Had a good time. Enjoyed seeing lots of familiar faces and some good swords. People are still submitting stuff they shouldn t, however. I do hope the level of
messages.messageBody:
Had a good time. Enjoyed seeing lots of familiar faces and some good
swords. People are still submitting stuff they shouldn't, however. I
do hope the level of study continues to improve. A lot of the guys
who have been with this for some time now did very well with some
only getting one or two rejections. Nonetheless, the younger and less
experienced guys need some guidance. I think the clubs are best for
that. Still, when the front desk tells you not to submit your
numbered and stamped gunto and you do anyway, I guess there is not
much that can be done. We are trying to have a traveling shinsa every
year with Chicago up next. I hope we can continue to see fewer
rejections. Oh, the show also seems to have been well attended on
Saturday. I gave a short talk similar to the one in San Francisco,
and it was a pretty good turn out for a one off event.

Gordon
